thread.title_full: Malheur County officials set meeting on Owyhee Canyonlands preservation plan

author: Terry Richard | The Oregonian/OregonLive
title: Malheur County officials set meeting on Owyhee Canyonlands preservation plan
text:
Comments 
Officials from Malheur County will hold a town hall meeting next week about the future of the Owhyhee Canyonlands, which make up much of the southern part of the county in southeastern Oregon. 
The meeting was announced in a news release from Oregon Rep. Cliff Bentz , who represents House District 60 and is from Ontario. Bentz said he will join Sen. Ted Ferrioli of John Day, Malheur County judge Dan Joyce and Malheur County commissioners Larry Wilson and Don Hodge at the meeting. 
The event will take place Thursday, Oct. 29, from 6:30 to 8:30 p.m., Mountain Daylight Time, at the high school gymnasium in Adrian, 305 Owyhee Road. Most of Malheur County is on mountain time, though the upper reaches of the Owyhee River in Oregon are on Pacific time. 
According to Bentz, as noted in the news release, the meeting is partly in response to a proposal by the Oregon Natural Desert Association of Bend and Keen Footwear of Portland leading a proposal for 2.5 million acres of the Owyhee Canyonlands to be protected as a national monument. Keen conducted a cross-country tour this summer to raise support for declaration of five national monuments. 
Owyhee County residents had previously looked at the proposal and said perhaps 1 million acres would be suitable for protection . The difference in acreage is largely the inclusion of vast areas of uplands, instead of just the canyons, in the environmentalists' proposal. 
This process only affects the Oregon portion of the Owyhee country, not the upper forks of the river and its tributaries in Idaho or Nevada. Idaho resolved most of its Owyhee land issues with legislation passed in 2009 . 
Bentz said that local citizens have formed Citizens in Opposition to the Owyhee Canyonlands Monument Committee as a counterpoint to the protection proposed by the Bend-based environmental group. The committee's website is opposetheocm.com . 
Both sides have established online petitions regarding federal protection the Owyhee. The Malheur County petition is at change.org and the environmentalists' petition is at wildowyhee.org . 
In his news release, Bentz said the "meeting will serve as an open forum for attendees to share their thoughts on the proposed establishment of an Owyhee Canyonlands designation, be it a national monument, national conservation area or wilderness area.'' -- Terry Richard
